author: peteranderson

description.text:
This is an old Viking game that I completely redesigned with my own graphics, game pieces, rule book and a handy box to store the game in. The plans are designed for 3mm MDF. This is a work in progress because I need to make some small changes to the design that will make the fit of the closing mechanism perfect. However, with some sanding here and there, the current files should do just fine. The hinge works perfectly without glue. The sides of the box and the playing pieces need to be glued. As an alternative to the laser cut playing pieces, I created 3D printable pieces for people that have no access to a laser cutter. I also included the board separately. Just print the board on paper, print 24 knights, 12 vikings and 1 king. With an Ultimaker 1, it took 9 minutes per piece at 50mm/s and 20% infiill. I am sure you will have lots of fun making and playing the game! Read more on my blog: http://make.petervdb.be/2016/01/02/hneftafl-the-viking-game/
Watch the video with the laser cutter in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p6H3IBfgdmI

A stand I created for a friend who is running an amiibo tournament. Awards are given in the form of flags, which can indicate overall placement in the tournament, as well as best in some particular stat category, such as "damage giver per kill," "life span," etc.
In the models, the "S1" that appears on the various flags stand for season one, when the award is given. The base is given to an amiibo at the time of their first participation.
(I also made some "Season 0" bases for amiibo that participated in past events)

description.text:
Brief: This is a double bearing design with integrated retainer. I had a few difficulties with my Rostock where it came to dealing with spools: 1) Spools did not want to turn freely on the spool holder.
2) The screw on the arm side of the holder would catch on spools.
3) The spool would jump over the lip of the stock holder.
4) All the above caused a variety of issues with printing. My solution was to create a couple of spool bearings (with large side walls) which addresses all the above issues. The way this is used is that the larger spool bearing is inserted first (and on the side going against the arm of the holder), and then the smaller bearing is inserted on the other side (toward the side that has the lip), then the spool with the two bearings are placed on the spool holder. Benefits and results:
1) Spools now spin VERY freely!
2) Spools no longer jump off the spindle!
3) Spool bearings work with every spool I've found!
4) Printing is now quieter because the spool no longer jumps around! I recommend printing this part in PLA, as PLA is harder than ABS and makes for a better bearing surface with less friction.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0gVVMRFXLs5

title: Spring Loaded Target for NERF Gun Fun!

description.text:
NERF Guns are popular all over the world and used for a bit of harmless fun at home, around the office / workplace and outdoors. It provides a new sporting / competitive dimension to NERF Gun fun.
The target itself is a moving one piece print with hinges. The second part is a small flat strip of PLA that is used as a return spring. Both parts only uses a bit over 60gm of PLA at recommended setting (including Raft). As an alternative to printing a PLA spring you can cut a similar size strip of flexi / springy plastic from an old plastic container of some sort.   
Allocate a specific number of NERF darts to each competitor and score their hits. This target makes it easy to see hits as it is spring loaded. You can hear a hit and see it spring back... then it pops back up and into place ready for the next shot. 
The target is easy to mount. Either use a couple of screws into a block of wood, a wooden bench, shelf or fence then slot into place. This makes it easily removable if you want. The alternative is to clip it onto a bench, table or shelf using a large bulldog clip.  
This is a great fun alternative to the usual 'human targets' NERF Guns are commonly used for... and it can become very competitive. 
Please refer to the print settings and images for additional information. 
Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

2 Shells / 20% infill minimum / PLA

Notes: 2 Shells / 20% infill makes the target adequately strong but, if you're happy to use a bit more filament (because you expect you'll use it a lot) increase to 3 shells and 30% infill to make it really strong... PLA is tough so it stands up to hits very well. Raft is recommended for easy removal from the build plate. Do not scale this down as it will affect the internal clearances used for the hinges. At standard scale the target measures 172.50mm x 116.50mm.

Remove the raft, insert the flexi spring and mount.... After Raft removal you need to insert the PLA flexi spring. This should easily slide into the thin slot in the lower centre of the target. Once installed just fold the target upright, mount it and you're good to go. You can use a strip of flexi plastic cut from an old plastic container as an alternative to using a printed PLA flat spring. This will change how springy / flexi the target is and its rate of return. Other plastics may in fact be better (PLA is hard so it snaps back quickly. Other types like polypropylene are softer so still return well but slower).

title: Hybridized Orbitals
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a set of hybridized orbitals based on BlendLabor's orbital shape. The set includes the basic sp hybridized orbital, sp, sp2, and sp3 models. Unhybridized p orbitals are also included that can be connected to the sp and sp2 models to show pi-bond orbital overlaps.
***This is a work in progress so the bond angles for the sp3 model are still a little bit off.
I recommend using hot glue to attach the unhybridized orbitals to the models.

Printer:

Da Vinci Jr.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

5-10%
Hot glue is recommended for connecting the unhybridized p orbitals to the other models to make them more stable for demonstrations.
NGSS CCSS

Molecules have three-dimensional shapes that are important to their function, especially in biological systems. This model helps students do visualize these shapes and the reasons that they form based on hybridization and VSEPR theory. Students will understand how orbitals combine when covalent bonds are formed. Students will be able to describe how the orbital shapes relate to VSEPR theory. Students will be able to describe the difference between pi and sigma bonds based on orbital overlap. Students will be able to relate orbital arrangement to molecular shape. Preparation:
Students should already be familiar with atomic orbitals as well as valence shell electron repulsions (VSEPR) theory. They should also be familiar with single, double, and triple covalent bonds.

Describe how s and p orbitals combine in order to form covalent bonds which repel to be as far apart as possible. These are known as hybrid orbitals.
This set can be combined with the atomic orbital set.
Draw a molecule that is tetrahedral and discuss how it needs for orbitals pointing in the correct directions to form. Show the relative positions of the s and p orbitals using the atomic orbital set first, then show how these 4 orbitals combine into four of the hybrid orbitals in this set. Show that the farthest these four orbitals can get from each other are 109.5° as shown in the sp3 model.
Next, draw a trigonal planar carbon molecule on the board with one double bond. Discuss how only three orbitals are needed so only 1 s orbital and 2 p orbitals combine to form three hybrid orbitals and the sp2 shape. Point out that there is a leftover p orbital. Use the provided unhybridized p orbitals to show how these stick out from the shape. Use a second sp2 model with attactched p orbitals to discuss how the double bond forms. This can then be used to differentiate sigma and pi bonds. More advanced classes can use these models to discuss bond rotation.
Draw a linear carbon molecule with a triple bond and a single bond. Repeat the procedure above noting that two p orbitals are left over. Use the sp model and unhybridized p orbitals to demonstrate the formation of two pi bonds with this geometry.
A molecular model kit will be helpful to have in order to shown how the hybridized orbitals translate into actual molecular shapes, types of bonds, and rotations around bonds.

title: 5mm - 7/32" Customizable Stacking Parts Box with Options
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This remix was originally because I wanted a bigger box and I wanted to use 5mm plywood (link below). I resized it and made it for my Grandfather as a Christmas gift. Then I decided that I needed one or two for different work areas and so I started tweaking it. So far, the options are:
  • Original Design (4 rows of drawers) resized for 5mm material
  • 2 row drawer version
  • 3 row drawer version
  • 9 row drawer/bookshelf version (more info below)
  • Double DIN drawers (the drawer takes up two rows instead of one)
  • Dividers, spacers, and tool holder customizations (work in progress)

Corel File:
It was made in CorelDraw X6. My laser software automatically assigns cut to red and scan to black. Black is by default inactive, so that's why the writing and optional parts are outlined in black (or blue). Blue is a color I use for cutting as well, usually for inner pieces so I can set them at a different speed or power, or cut them in a separate pass from the red parts. These parts are ganged (fit together) to optimize material use, but they ARE NOT WELDED! (I prefer to cut fitted parts in 2 passes for multiple reasons.) You can separate them or weld them as you like. I tried to order the objects so that the laser won't bounce all around the sheet while cutting (I haven't tested whether it worked or not yet). Material:
I bought this 5mm plywood at Home Depot: http://www.homedepot.com/p/Unbranded-Underlayment-Common-7-32-in-x-4-ft-x-8-ft-Actual-0-196-in-x-48-in-x-96-in-431178/203183010
I like it a lot, Lowe's did not have anything as nice.
FYI - I also bought this: http://www.homedepot.com/p/Columbia-Forest-Products-1-4-in-x-4-ft-x-8-ft-PureBond-Birch-Plywood-165891/100092485
because it's formaldehyde free...well, forget it. The end product is nice, but it creates an insane amount of acrid, thick smoke that took 20 minutes each time for my exhaust to clear, and I was constantly having to clean my mirrors and lenses. 9 Drawer/Bookshelf:
I wanted to have some drawers, but also store my books and magazines, so this was an experiment. I haven't tried it yet though. It's about 20 inches tall and in theory, you can have 9 rows of drawers, or 3 rows of drawers and about 12 inches of book room, enough for a few 3 ring binders. Problems:
After designing the bookshelf, I realized that the unit is only about 7" deep, which will not hold a 3-ring binder. So I went about designing a deeper unit that's about 10" deep (which still won't work for binders, do'h!) But it will work for most books and you can also use it as a file tray if you leave a row of drawers out. (Still working on the deeper version, I'll post it soon.) Because the design is larger than the original, you can't really put the largest drawer on the bottom because it bears all the weight. It really needs the 4 small drawers with their dividers to give it support, but I've found that any of the configurations with at least one divider in there works fine (again, I haven't tried the 9 drawer unit yet though).

description.text: This special star-shaped nut is commonly used for gripping weight wheels to dumbbell rods.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Graber i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: RECOMMENDED SETTINGS: print with no support, 0.2mm. Use a medium to large wall thickness and infill for improved resistance, specially if printing with ABS. I recommend at least 5 walls (top/bottom also) and 30% infill. If you print in polycarbonate you can use a little less. I strongly recommend you use a hard filament to print this design. ABS will do fine, but polycarbonate is even better. If you print in PLA it will probably be too brittle, don't hold me responsible if it breaks.

My nuts were getting loose so I printed these I have a couple of dumbbells at my home gym and the star nuts holding the weights were getting loose. I tried to find the exact measurements of these nuts on the net so that I could model or buy some extra parts, but I couldn't find it anywhere. So I grabbed a caliper and just measured the thing, then gone through several iterations (8) until I got a part that fitted exactly on my dumbbell rods. Although I could not get the measurements online, from pictures it seems that most if not all dumbbells use the same screw sizes - even the pitch and the spiral direction seems to match. So I think it's highly likely that this design will fit on other dumbbell brands. I have used the public domain library polyscrewthread, which I include here. Just put it in the same directory and it should work. I have made two versions. The first one is the final design which I printed and fitted perfectly on my dumbbell. However, I have a FDM printer which "overextrudes" about 0.2mm outward in the horizontal plane due to the 0.4mm nozzle. So, if you use a non-FDM printer which does not everextrudes, or you use XY compensation in your slicer, or you somehow manage to get exact measures with what you print, I also made an "-exact" version which has "exact" measurements for the nut to work. So, if you print the nut and it is too loose, you might try this one which has a slightly smaller hole. Also, if you are reading this and you know where to find the measurements information that I couldn't find, I'd gladly thank you for telling. :)

I started with YAFC
yet another filament clip.
I put 4 of them on a 0.5mm brim to prevent corner lifting.
print em out and break em apart - trim with scissors the original yafc needs to be scaled up 2500%
these 4 are correct - do not scale them.
each clip should be 25mm long when done REVISION: filament_clips.stl
I was having a slight problem with my clips letting go so...
I modified the YAFC. I duplicated it and flipped it over onto itself and combined them. The result is a slightly wider clip, with a center channel and two outside channels with the little pressure buttons. I put 4 on a common brim for easy printing. trim with scissors or your favorite tool.

comments.text: Haha I love your enthusiasm. I've got an Ultimaker on order and I'll print one of these when it comes in. Keep up on your 3D modelling and learning - it will definitely pay off!
comments.author: tlalexander

comments.text: so why did you choose an ultimaker and not thing-o-matic? Thanks and i will just keep saving for one!
comments.author: tlalexander

comments.text: I'd say the two biggest things the Ultimaker has over the TOM is large sized print area, and very fast.  since the motors are stationary, the head can move around much more rapidly than other printers.  As the software improves, and they get the filament feeding to be more reliable (my experience), I'd say the Ultimaker is a very nice alternative to a TOM (which I don't actually have).
comments.author: futureconnections

comments.text: But the thing for me is price point and the TOM is 829 in the uk where the Ultimaker is 1029!
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: If you're trying to go cheap (like me ^^) i suggest you look at a Reprap Prusa Mendel, preferably the LM8UU version: http://richrap.blogspot.com/2011/08/pimp-my-mendel-how-to-build-up-lm8uu.htmlhttp://richrap.blogspot.com/20... . It has an 200x200x ~150mm build envelope and you'll probably want to self-source most parts.
comments.author: futureconnections

comments.text: I had the money for either and I went with a RepRap.  I still would.  The TOM didn't really make any sense to me - why would I pay a lot more for a machine with a build area the size of a postage stamp?

This Thing is a MakerBot 3D Portrait of Fred scanned at the MakerBot Retail Store in SoHo on Jul 26, 2013.  These scans are at 1/4th the original size.

• Preview each model by clicking the thumbnail on the top left. Click on the cube to see the model in 3D.
  • Download the STL of the file you would like to print. The first thumbnail corresponds to portrait_1, and so on.
  • Open the STL in MakerWare or ReplicatorG, resize as necessary and print.

This is my first 3d design, which I made for my Printrbot Simple Metal.  I am using Harchbox filiment and these filiment rolls do not have a notch inside the arbor for them to ride on the spool holder, so the roll would ride against the z axis rods.  If I wanted to print something tall, the z axis motor would hit the filiment spool and my print would fail.  I used a toilet paper tube and cardboard for a temporary fix until I got this printed.  Now I am able to print the entire length of the z axis with monitoring the print.

author: paisita77

title: Star Wars X-wing: AT-ST and conversion kit

description.text:
I wish FFG would make ground vehicles for the X-wing miniatures game, but so far they have not. This set of files will allow you to add AT-STs to your game. They have been a lot of fun for Epic/scenario/just for fun style games. (I've been using Attack 1, Defense 1, Hull 2, Focus action only, 0 and all the 1's for movement.) First, you’ll need the X-Wing style base. It has the same dimensions as the FFG 'small' fighter base. The 90 degree lines are for checking firing arc. The posts in back hold the ID tag. Second you'll need an AT-ST model. There are several beautiful models available online but none of them would print cleanly for me at 1:270 scale - they had /too much/ detail. So I created my own model and included it here. I’ll be the first to tell you that it is missing much of the detail of the larger models, but on the tabletop in this small size they look fine to me. I was planning to print a bunch of these for my game and I don’t want them to look exactly the same. There are 6 different leg positions to choose from. The head is a separate piece that needs to be glued on, but this allows you to build each one slightly different. If you are truly ambitious you can file the neck a little bit so the head is looking up or down. All models are to be printed at 100% scale.
The flight base is printed bottom down, no supports.
The head is printed with the guns pointing up, no supports.
The legs are printed with the feet flat on the print bed and supports turned on. Normally I hate cleaning off supports but gluing and pinning thin little legs to the body was not that appealing, so I went with the lesser of two evils. At least they are small. One other note, I had better results printing the AT-ST heads in groups of two or more. As the extruder nozzle moves from one individual part to the next it gives the plastic time to cool down and solidify between layers. (On my first ‘test print’ of a single head, the tall, skinny chin gun turned into a blob of plastic.) Finally, I included a 1.25" tall cylinder should you decide to use a different model. First, place the cylinder on the virtual build plate of your printing software. Then put the AT-ST model on the build plate. Keep adjusting the scale of the AT-ST until the top of the cylinder is at the top of the model's head. Finally, delete the cylinder and print. This way you know your AT-ST will be 1.25" tall. This is the correct scale for games of X-wing.
[An AT-ST is listed as 8.6 meters tall, I will leave you to do the math yourself. Note that the leg position makes the model taller or shorter so 1.25 is a rough number.] Happy gaming

This file is a free download.  Please note that it is listed as “non-commercial”.  Neither you nor I are allowed to buy or sell physical copies of this 3D model.   You are allowed (and encouraged) to print copies for your own personal use.  If you have been re-directed to this file from a source other than my site on thingiverse.com they have done so without my permission.  Thank you for respecting the rights of the original copyright holder.

comments.text: I'm new to 3d printing and was wondering how much it cost and how long it takes to print this
comments.author: ellioto123

comments.text: I printed these about a year and a half ago so I'll just have to estimate (rather than remember).  A small model like this would take about an hour to print and use about 25 cents worth of PLA.  You'll also spend another 10-15 minutes carefully removing the supports from around the legs and guns.
comments.author: ellioto123

comments.text: I like the paintjob (on this one and on the at-at) - any advice how you did that?
comments.author: schn1tzelteller

comments.text:
After printing, spray with the cheapest medium gray spray paint you can find. The finish (gloss, matte, etc) does not matter. Then drybrush the whole model with a lighter gray acrylic paint (I use GW) over the top of that. If you want to get crazy, do a second very light drybrush over the top of that using white. Paint in any details (I believe I painted the windows red on the AT-ATs) you want to add, then finally spray the whole model with clear matte to blend everything together and protect the paint.
You won't win any painting awards but they look nice enough on the tabletop.
comments.author: schn1tzelteller

author: Hazardrockone

description.text: With my partner, I'm building a tiny museum called The Mμseum. We wanted to have a track lighting system similar to what one would find in a full-size museum. This lets the curator light pieces individually to help set off works in different ways. Each spot light is posable and has a can to create a crisp light cone. This is a miniature track lighting system using standard through-hole 6mm LEDs as the light sources. The tracks themselves are simply stiff wires that run in parallel along the ceiling, holding the lights in place with magnets. This is designed to have 5V 1A rails and can support up to 25 LED spot lights. Note: the notch to mark the polarity shown in the photos is inverted from the files here. After creating the photographed ones, I realized that it'd make more sense to publish with the notches matching that of LEDs (marking the negative/cathode instead of the anode). The source files of the openSCAD files are in the The Mµseum git repository

See the included photos for all the parts and steps.  
Individual spot ingredients list

• LED (warm white, 5mm, Digikey part 1080-1006-ND)
  • 82Ω resistor, ¼W, 3mm (Digikey part S82QCT-ND) file can be easily tweaked for larger resistors.
  • LED spot shade (led_spot_shade.scad)
  • super glue
  • LED spot magnet holder (led_spot_magnet_holder.scad)
  • 2× cube magnets (4mm to each side. Unfortunately, the source I got mine dried up when they became illegal to sell. The magnet holder file can be automatically-adjusted to fit any size cube magnets by tweaking the magnet_size parameter.)
  • magnet wire (22 gauge, 50mm wire per spot)
  • reflector: thin, flexible shiny material that can be bent into a cylinder (I used some scrap metalized anti-static bags) 10x26mm rectangle per spot
  • if the magnet wire is not ferrous, scrap ferrous wire (a 3-4mm sections per spot. I used scraps cut from the resistor leads, which were ferrous)
    • Tools

• soldering iron, solder
  • needle-nose pliers
  • scissors or knife
  • sandpaper or a metal file
    • LED can

Prepare the LED spot shade by ensuring that there are two holes at the bottom. If the 3D print didn't come out well, a knife or awl can be used to punch/ream a hole in the bottom. Put the LED leads into the shade and glue the LED it into place using super glue.  
Cut out a 10x26mm rectangle of the reflector material and roll it into a cylinder. This should have about 2mm of overlap on the long side to ensure full coverage. If it has one side that's shinier than the other, ensure that the shiny side is on the inside. Place this between the LED shade and the LED itself, to act as a light reflector and to block the light from causing the shade to glow.  
Wiring

Cut off two 25mm lengths of magnet wire and sand off the wire coating. I've done about 5mm on each end, sanding until the wire is shiny.  
If the magnet wire isn't ferrous, solder a 3mm section of scrap ferrous wire along side one end of each piece of the magnet wire. This will be placed under the magnet and allow it to stick to the wire, creating a strong electrical contact.  
Then place the wire with the ferrous metal on it through the center hole in the LED spot magnet holder. This will be your + connection.  
Bend one of the resistor's leads into a flat spiral such that it can make good contact underneath the magnet. Solder the other piece of magnet wire to the other lead and feed it through the non-center hole. This will be your - connection.  
Solder the + connection to the positive side of the LED. Make a loop of the magnet wire and hook them together before soldering. If you look into the LED itself, the positive side is connected to the smaller half of the metal part inside the LED (if you look closely, there are two halves, one notably smaller than the other, connected via a tiny wire).  
The remaining side should be soldered to the - connection in the same fashion.  
Magnets

Insert the magnets into the two cubical recesses in the LED spot magnet holder. You may need pliers to get them to stay in. They can be kept in place using a drop of super glue (be careful to not block the electrical connection).  
Rails
For the rails, I used piano wire. The main criteria is that it is stiff and ferrous. I had hoped to use flat strips of metal, but couldn't find any that are 4mm wide.

title: Toy Dump Truck (split)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a cut-up version of barspin's Toy Dump Truck (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:537153) which I had wanted to print as close to the intended scale as possible, but my tiny printer could not managed even at 50% scale. So I had to chop up the 3 main parts of the truck into halves. The wheels and axles were able to fit so I did not modify them and they are not included in the files here. I used this technique in Fusion 360 to make the split - https://screencast.autodesk.com/main/details/058c63ba-23c4-4b96-a218-d86a52afbadd Fillets have also been added to the corners that turned out somewhat still pointy in the print. This should make it safer as a toy for toddlers. Another modification I did was the slight lengthening of the pivot pins on the flatbed while at the same time stretching the pivot holes on the base into through-holes. This is to make the flatbed more secure once attached to the base. To overcome the difficulty of slotting the longer pins into the holes, I simply heated one of the ears of the hinge with the flame from a lighter for a few seconds. This allowed me to bend it a little without breaking it. Once I have bent it enough to insert the pivot pins, I quickly pressed that ear back in place and held it firmly there until it has completely cooled. I still had to scale this split version slightly down in the slicer (0.93x) in order to fit my M3D printer.

Mount any camera with a standard-sized mount hole to your Pack-n-Play so you can watch your baby from anywhere in the world!

description.text: This is V2 of DJI Phantom Pitch Control Lever. We simplified the design and improved durability. DJI Phantom transmitter has a hidden 7th channel which can be manipulated to control the pitch of the gimbal with 3d printable pitch control lever. Now you can comfortably adjust pitch position of your camera while flying your Phantom. This empowers you to do amazing aerial shots! 3d printable pitch control lever is attached at the back of the phantom transmitter and fits perfectly. Nothing extra is required! Designed by https://www.bustmold.com/locations/ottawa/ and https://www.bustmold.com/locations/montreal/

Tested on Replicator 2.
Works perfectly at basic settings:

remixed_from.title: TAZ Raspberry Pi Camera Case & Mount

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Mount for Taz

description.text: This is a simple fixture for mounting a Raspberry Pi camera to the T-slot on the frame of a Taz printer. Included are files for three bend angles (110, 115 and 120 degrees) for slightly different views of the print bed. There are two versions with the 110 deree bend, for mounting on the left or right side of the Taz frame. The cable slot on the 110 degree version has been opened in the front. This allows the camera to be inserted or removed without disconnecting the ribbon cable. I added a version with a 120 degree bend for mounting on the left side of the Taz 5 frame. This one allows you to see the print head when it is positioned at the far left. This can be secured to the frame using a Twist-In T Slot Nut. This part was designed to mount to the Taz 5 frame using a M5, 12 mm screw.

title: Beer bottle or can rack for fridge

description.text:
This stubbie beer bottle (or can) rack is really simple to print and can be expanded to any size you like by just connecting more sections.  My original 4 bottle design would be a very tight fit to print one on a 200mm square print bed.  If you have a 300mm x 200mm print bed like me you can print 6 of these at a time.  I will upload a 3 bottle design soon that will easily fit a 200mm square bed and may even squeeze onto a 150mm square bed.
Update - I have now added variants for 1, 2 and 3 long bottle holders.  Clearly the 1 long holder won't work by itself but could be a useful addition to a longer rack.  If you make a rack that is say 3 long and hinge a 1 long rack on each end then they can be folded down when you want to store a lot of bottles and folded up for times when you only want to store a few bottles - but you want to liberate more shelf space for other things in the fridge - maybe even food!

After printing, run a 3mm drill thru all the holes and join the sections together with 100mm long pieces of bamboo kebab skewer (or 110mm long for joining pieces to fit multiple sections together to make a longer rack).  I found there is a bit of variation in the diameter of skewers with several in a pack being a nice tight fit in the 3mm hole and others being loose.  I'd suggest test fitting skewers before opening up the holes with a drill.  The basic 4 bottle design safely holds a pyramid of 10 beers in the fridge. Any more than 3 rows high you would probably be better to stand the bottles up.  With 4 sections you can join them to make it anywhere from 5 to 8 bottles long but just varying the overlap.

I was getting sick of my beers rolling around on the shelf in the fridge and I couldn't find a design I liked for a beer bottle/can holder so I designed my own.  I wanted something that was quick to print, elegant and functional.  The key to the success of this design was the kebab sticks to join the pieces together.  This allowed for the printed parts to be very simple with no overhangs or bridging and very little plastic, while still producing a secure rack.  An added advantage is that they allow for the rack to be easily extended with more sections.

description.text:
!!!!!////////////////////////////////// OUT OF DATE ////////////////////////////////////// !!!!!
/////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
Since This was Published Sparkfun has retired the PGM-11460 Programmer that this
was originally designed to work with and replaced it with the PGM-11801. Which adds
an extra solder pad to the end of the board which causes the solder joints on the DIP
to not align with the recess in the design. I'm going to leave this here for anyone who has the PGM-11406 which should work and
for anyone who might want to remix it to be compatible with the new board design. Again
This is not compatible with the new revision of the programmer available from Sparkfun.
///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// Housing for the Sparkfun Tiny AVR Programmer. Fair Warning I am still using 1.2 and have yet to print a 1.3. The only changes between the two was the notch to secure the two halves was too close to the upper layer of the lower housing. So for 1.3 the lower housing walls were raised slightly adding more structure above the notch and the top was adjusted accordingly.

When printing make sure you rotate the top 180 so the flat surface is on the bed of your printer. I keep doing that manually and forgetting to change the actual STL.  
The Programmer should fit into the lower housing with little trouble, there is a slight lip at the far end to assist. However I found the fit to be tight enough that it wasn't needed. Then simply snap on the top.

comments.text: Sorry about that, apparently the retired the PGM-11460 and replaced it with the PGM-11801. Which adds a pad for an additional connector at the end which pushes the DIP package farther back. I don't want to take it down in case someone wants to remix it and move/expand the hole for the solder joints on the DIP but I will make a note of it on the page.

description.text: My 2nd successfully created cookie-cutter.

Printer:

DaVinci 2.0A Duo

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

90 (full)

Notes: I've printed it with 90fill (full), slow speed, 0.2 stepsize, normal wall-thickness and model slices in the XYZware with these settings. Note that slicing should give you a double-wall with no holes.

Brushed with Acetone For finishing, I've brushed the printed design with Acetone to prevent delaminating of the layers. This gives the cutter some "glossiness" as well.
The Acetone "dissolves" the ABS, so it can be used to smoothen as well as glue it. First time, I've done this, and it seems to work perfectly. Protection:
Do wear protective gear and do not inhale fumes when working with Acetone!

Done in Blender 2.76 by manually drawing the shape based on a bitmap and using extrude and solidify-modifier plus mesh-cleanup steps. Sliced in XYZware giving double-walls without holes. The ZIP file contains the STL file, but also the resulting 3w file and the original Blender file for modification. Blender Details
  • Start with scene, delete default object (in Edit mode)
  • Add "shape" bitmap in Z-projection (optional)
  • Create vertex loop (CTRL clicking), closed
  • Scale such, that 10 Blender units represent 10mm
  • clean-up loop (add/remove vertices), smooth etc.
  • Duplicate object (in Object mode) to have one for "upper" and one for "lower" part.
  • Extrude (in Edit mode) lower part 3 units downwards
  • Ensure face-normals point outward (Recompute normals if needed)
  • In Object mode, apply "Solidify modifier", no offset, thickness 0.5
  • Extrude (in Edit mode) upper part 10 units upwards
  • Ensure face-normals point outward (Recompute normals if needed)

  • In Object mode, apply "Solidify modifier", no offset, thickness 0.15

  • In Object mode, select both parts, then File/Export as STL

Final sliced model (3w file) - GOOD SLICING When slicing the design, the outcome should show a double-wall with no gaps in between. I get this with the before mentioned settings for the STL model as stored. The critical thing here is the "wall thickness" set in Blender. If the wall gets thicker or thinner, the slicing produces not so nice models. See below: Bad slicing. The gaps will reproduce in the print.

description.text: An alternative design for the RepRap Darwin Z endstop. It allows the machine to home the z-axis away from the workpiece, so that homing is always a safe operation, regardless of what state the machine is in. More details in my blog: http://hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2008/08/alternative-z-endstop.html

Print the parts with a RepRap. If your ABS is not opaque to IR you will need to paint it with something that is or wrap it in tin foil. I used black BBQ paint.
Fasten the tab to a bed corner bracket with two M5x15 bolts. Attach the opto PCB to the opto bracket with two M3x12 bolts and fasten the bracket to a vertical post with an M4x20 bolt.
Adjust the opto bracket angle so that the tab clears the slot and set its height to where you want the z-limit to be.

Notes: Print in ABS and acetone weld the parts together, or use PLA and SuperGlue (which is what I used on this build).

Assembly Print in ABS and acetone weld the parts together, or use PLA and SuperGlue (which is what I used on this build). Because of the board layout on the supplied kit, I didn't mount the power input socket on the board, instead gluing it to a more convenient place on the rear stand leg, and running leads from the socket to the PCB. In the pictures you can see that after mounting the board, I pushed stiff conductive wire through the holes into the anode receptacles on the PCB - in retrospect, if I assembled this kit again, I wouldn't bother with the receptacles, I would just push the LED anode legs straight into the PCD and solder them in place. I also found it useful to glue the switch cover in place on the PCB mounted switch before mounting the board.

This is a mount for the 20mm cable chain which was created by Techwiz below. The chain has a 20mm spacing which was enough to house the cabling for both of my extruders on my Geeetech Prusa i3x printer. Since this printer is an acrylic printer and the X-Axis sits forward for the main frame, I had to come up with a way to mount this chain correctly still allow for the cables to move freely and connect to the GT2560 board. I will be posting pictures of the installed extruders with the cable chain once I have it all together. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:934604 You will notice in the picture that I took that the holes do not show up. Those were added today to see how it would the object would look and fit. I like the design and I want to thank Techwiz for the initial design. I have also added a design for an angled bracket which will help push the wiring toward the back of the printer from the chain. This is not necessary but thought that I would give a design a try that would redirect the wiring. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fF6Q9zeSCAB

title: Front Lower Chassis Plate - 1/10 Quanum Vandal 4WD

description.text: If you own a Quanum Vandal you must know by now that it breaks a lot :) This is the Front Lower Chassis Plate - 1/10 Quanum Vandal 4WD. It has been simplified so it is not an exact copy of the original, It lacks the bumper mount and is a little bit longer in front. It also is a little bit thicker so it does not break that easy. You might need slightly longer bolts to bolt it on because of the increased thickness.  Print at 100% infill at maximum temperature, support is also required.

title: Customizable Gear Puller that actually works!!!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to buy a gear puller, but why do not print it? There is one on TW which does not work, it's too weak.  
There are some issues. The plastic is strong when there is much of it. It does not work, when we try to pull the gear with plastic edges.  
So, I made the edges of steal. I have used rivets that are widely available. I think This is the spirit of printing. No suitable tool? Think and Print it! No matter, that almost every tool which increases force is made of steel. Made of ABS works too! And even does not squeak and break neither!  
The rivets are placed at the angle to the layers, so the thing is strong as every layer keeps the rivets in place during screwing-in the shaft-push-screw  
I have pulled successfully the gear without destroying it !!! (Which I wanted the most!!!)  
I have tried another gear, but which was secured by make the shaft end a little wider. No success, however the puller didn't broke, even so I have used all my force I had in pliers (the screwdriver gave up before this) and even so i put the puller into jaws of vice  the gear didn' move.   
On the picture you see my Gear Puller with partially pulled out gear. I have too short M5 screw...

Well, I think it's the best to print the Gear Puller with 1.0 fill, two perimeters, and even give some overextrude (I have used 110%).  
The print time is about one hour, with 0.334 layer thick and 80 mm/s speed, 0 degrees fill skew.

comments.text: How many rivets and which sizes? Thanks for sharing this.

title: Project BioLab-MYCO, the Automatic DST testing device for Tuberculosis

description.text:
UPDATE
The result of Project BioLab-MYCO had been published! (SCI-E, IF 2.0)
Kim, Kyukwang, et al. "A Low Cost/Low Power Open Source Sensor System for Automated Tuberculosis Drug Susceptibility Testing." Sensors 16.6 (2016): 942. Project BioLab-MYCO is the project dedicated to develop an affordable automatic device for DST (Drug Sensitivity Test) of Tuberculosis. Based on NRA (Nitrate Reductase Assay) method, it detects the growth of mycobacteria. Using Arduino, this provides very affordable and convenient automatic diagnosis method to be used in developing nations.

  • Motor holder, Linear servo linker, Color sensor holder and Ogawa medium holder, which are printed via 3D printer (Makerbot Replicator 2X) are presented here.

  • More information is available at https://github.com/W5-KAIST/BioLabMYCO

Nobody smokes any more, so why not use an ashtray for something ... useful? This is an insert which fits in an Infiniti G35's ashtray (2003 and other similar models, perhaps). You can customize the SKP to add whatever you want. In my case, I've installed:
  • one switch to enable my nav hack,
  • one switch to turn off my CarPC,
  • two USB ports.
    • Note: to fit the USB connectors, I had to take some significant plastic out of the innards of the ashtray.

print_settings.Resolution:: 0.1mm up past the nose and then the rest at 0.2mm

description.text: The ormerod 2 comes with an acrylic piece (781) to attach a cooling fan. Sans shroud i decided to put it to use and design my own for use together with a 40x40x10 akasa fan.

Printer:

Ormerod 2 528.4

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm up past the nose and then the rest at 0.2mm

Infill:

25% Archimedean Chords

Notes: Vertical shells: 3 layers
Horizontal shells Top: 3 layers
Horizontal shells Bottom: 3 layers
Filament: Verbatim white PLA 1.75mm
Hotend temperature: 185°C
Heated bed temperature: 65°C

The upper hole on my print sagged due to printing with no cooling fan. It was drilled out with a 3mm drill. It will hinge between the acrylic part and the EM shield. To further tether it to the acrylic piece, cut a length of Q-tip and insert into one/both holes on the side.
The ormerod hotend was first drawn up and assembled in solidworks so i had a "go no-go" area to work around.

comments.text:
design looks good in picture, but I found it impossible to print without a cooling fan - the section that curves up immediately from the base tends to warp up and foul the printer head. I will look at modifying the designto make the edge square
regards
Geoff

description.text: I purchased the wonderful Hyphae Calyx and Bromeliad lamps from Nervous System (http://n-e-r-v-o-u-s.com/blog/?p=6986). I had a lampfitting that did not fit perfectly and I wanted to make a bottom plate to seal it. It looks nice too, you can print color variations. description.text:

title: Makerfarm i3v Greg's Accessible Extruder as bowden

description.text:
I got unpleasant surprise, when last piece of filament fall in X belt and almost burn my motor. Therefore I decided to convert my prusa i3v to bowden config.
I ordered teflon tube and fittings in ebay. As a usual I got wrong 1/8" size that doesnt fit to my hexagon hotend. I printed out simple converter pices. Finally it works almost the same as previous, only distance for refraction should be 4.5mm instead 1.5mm before. Next Im going to add filament end sensor to be safe when spool ends next time.
Tube, fittings, some M4 bolts and plastic clamps cost me ~10$ + 4 hours to print and assemble.

title: Power Plug with switch and fuse for Prusa I3 3D printer

description.text:
My printer Prusa I3 (M-505) have just a terminal block : this is really not practical to switch on/off. But browsing the Chinese sites, I came across this item(http://www.dx.com/fr/p/electrical-power-control-on-off-rocker-switches-with-indicator-light-fuse-base-139918#.VoeVGhXhCUk​)
Note That item contains a fuse holder but not supplied fuse. I recommend a fuse of 0.8 or 1 Ampere (180W power supply): A link to an assortment to 3E: http://www.dx.com/fr/p/bonatech-5-x-20mm-250v-glass-tube-fuse-pack-silver-transparent-50-pcs-0-5a-20a-303571#.VofN9xXhCUk. You will need:

  • A classic cable cord (PC type)

  • 2 items described above (DX, Ali, BG ...)

  • some 0.75 mm² wire (took on the original cord)

  • The cover printed in 3D

  • Required DIY (soldering iron, pliers, screwdrivers ...)
    • As can be seen, I expected a "tongue" in my object to put the screws, but on my printer model, I could use the original screws. For the front screws: screwdriver by the switch hole
    For the other screw : litle hole on the right side for the screwdriver. Use a multimeter and check my photos for electric wire (need skills) .

author: mzapata

description.text:
This cable chain can be opened and closed
Do not let the printed sit too attached to your bed.
After printing, gently move the shutter to move freely, then push the chain link together carefully.
Printed with PLA, 0.15 layer height.
The idea is that it should not be two parts but the subject comes out together.
There are many who have made a chain link into two parts.
There should be no more support than shown in the pictures, as little as possible and only where shown, and my topic is very nice as it is visible that faces outwards.
I want this to show, that it is possible to print the moving parts together without having to click several parts together.

comments.text: awesome chain !  the best ive found.. great design, good stuff    thanks a lot Elpo

comments.text: Glad that you can use my design, and thanks for the nice words

comments.text: Thanks for this awesome cable chain design. I've been using it for a few months now and really love the clean movement and easy cable access. Printing was simple - just printed a bed full of them and snapped them together.
comments.author: jmtx

comments.text: Just printing my third set of 6! I've got them in purple, silver, and now green. I really like the concept of having a captive snap closure - no parts to get lost. If PIP with the closure out to the side, and minimal support, they do work very well. Just be careful on that first flex  to get the closure to move, wiggle it a bit at first. My first 2 sets were printed with a raft, this set I decided to not waste filament and it's working just fine. PLA 195/50. About 2 1/2 hours to print 6.Thanks for a great design and execution, Elpo!

description.text: This is an 80mm hollow regular dodecahedron i.e. a regular polyhedron made up of regular pentagons. It is comprised of 11 out of 12 faces, plus a separate "lid".

Printer:

Wanhao 4S

Getting tired of buying special expensive one-purpose batteries?
Batteries with less power than the ones that you already have at home?
I were, so thats why I made this adapter for my hunting radio replaces an 800mah battery with a 3000mah.
I already changed the cells in the original battery pack a couple of years ago and now it was time again so why don't use something already ready?
Of course if you like you can print a bigger battery pack with the power you like as i will enclose the scad files.
Just to modify as you like
As batteries loses power at minus degrees when hunting in the winter I also got the option to have the battery in my inner pocket if I like and a wire to the pocket where the radio is.
Have fun!!
/Ice

author: SilverRidge

description.text: Super-sized version of the mini tape gun.  This version fits a regular 3 inch roll of packing tape.
Hot glue the parts together.  Sharpen the cutter teeth using a metal file and a lighter.  Hammer the end caps into the spool.  Put some lubricant on the threads.

The small tape roll from the mini version is 1 inch inner diameter and .5 inch thick.  The large tape roll is 3 inch inner diameter and 2 inch thick.
I scaled the print by by 2.994 / 1.020 in X and Y axis.  Scaled by 1.916 / .494 in the Z axis.
Meshmixer, OpenSCAD, Netfabb were used to cut and scale the parts.  I made the roller from scratch in OpenSCAD.
